awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Research Experience for Teachers in Nanoengineering with a Focus on Teacher Leadership
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to support a Research Experiences for K-12 Teachers (RET) in Nanotechnology, Engineering, and Leadership at Rice University entitled, "Research Experience for Teachers in Nanoengineering with a Focus in Leadership". This proposal leverages STEM programs developed through prior RET site and NSF Engineering Research Center awards that have resulted in a strong partnership with Houston Independent School District (HISD), which has a very diverse student population. The Rice RET is designed to not only develop content and leadership skills but also scale up research experiences by forming a nexus of teacher leaders who can then train new teachers in perpetuity. Teacher interns will work with curriculum specialists to develop lessons that are inquiry-based, embedded with nanoscience and engineering, and tightly aligned with National and Texas Science standards. The proposed NSF RET Program will enhance and extend the previous successful RET Program.

The Rice Office of STEM Engagement (R-STEM) will offer a K-12 RET program in Nanotechnology with a Focus on Teacher Leadership, an enhancement upon the six years of success Rice University has committed in teacher professional development through research internships. R-STEM will connect STEM teachers who serve students in the Greater Houston metropolitan area with expert faculty in nanoengineering research at Rice. With the help of Rice University's research mentorship and facilities, RET will accomplish the following objectives: 1) use nanoengineering research experiences to enhance teacher content knowledge and understanding of STEM research processes, 2) improve the quality of education though the development of engineering design-based learning activities centered on research practices, 3) create a cadre of teacher leaders, and 4) disseminate the RET outcomes broadly by creating a network of teachers who are actively learning about nanoengineering research and engineering design. Teachers will receive inquiry-based lessons, professional development, and pedagogical support along with leadership training as they translate their research experiences into learning experiences for students. The program will serve as a national model and will broadly disseminate the outcomes of RET via symposiums at Rice, national and state-wide meetings, peer-reviewed publications, and online via the TeachEngineering digital library. Teachers will meet weekly during their RET experience to discuss their research, share their lab experiences, develop lesson ideas, as well as plan the dissemination of their research. Rice postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and industry mentors will be constituents supporting the RET teachers in their research. At the conclusion of the research experience, each teacher will create a research poster to present their experience and finding at the Nanotechnology for Teachers Symposium, to their teaching campus, as well as at district and professional conferences. During the academic school year following their research experiences, teachers will share both their research and lesson plans with other teachers in professional development programs. R-STEM professional development courses will support RET teachers to propagate their knowledge effectively to a large number of STEM teachers, creating a cadre of motivated, creative, and diverse teacher leaders in the community. RET interns will also be encouraged and guided by the R-STEM team to publish their nanotechnology lessons through TeachEngineering.org. Throughout the components of the program, assessment is performed by an external evaluator to determine the impact on the 12 teachers that participate each summer and to provide feedback for refining the program.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
From 2017 to 2022, RET Site: Research Experience for Teachers in Nanoengineering with a Focus on Teacher Leadership program at Rice University successfully immersed a total of 81 Houston area 5-12th grade science teachers in 6 weeks of hands-on laboratory research experiences, team-building and professional development activities, followed by curriculum development workshops and dissemination of lesson plans. 

As part of the summer RET program, teacher participants gained valuable research experience and had the opportunity to collaborate with their peers. Teachers participated in the Annual Research Symposium for Teachers, where they showcased their research experience in the form of a poster presentation. The symposium served as a valuable space for networking and building connections with the broader scientific and educational community. 

In the fall and spring of each academic year, RET participants worked closely with curriculum experts to translate their research experiences into meaningful classroom lessons and ensure that their lessons aligned seamlessly with the 5-12th grade science TEKS, enhancing the educational impact on their students. The commitment to curriculum development was reflected in the publication of 35 lessons on TeachEngineering.org and 26 whiteboard videos on NanoHub since 2017. These resources are available to the wider teacher audience in the Houston area, the state, and the nation. 

Overall, the RET Site: Research Experience for Teachers in Nanoengineering with a Focus on Teacher Leadership at Rice University demonstrated its effectiveness by providing hands-on research experiences and aligning the research with 5-12th grade science TEKS. The program successfully contributed to increased diversity and inclusion in the field of nanotechnology research. The positive outcomes, including collaborative efforts, symposium presentations, interactions with Rice faculty and curriculum experts, and publication of lessons for other educators, are indicative of its impact on the participants and the broader scientific community. 

 

Published Whiteboard Videos on NanoHub: 

  1. Water from Urine

  2. Nanosilver and DBPs

  3. Selective Microbial Control in Drinking Water Systems Using Bacteriophages Conjugated with Superparamagnetic Nanoparticles

  4. PhotoBleaching

  5. Boron Nitrate Nanotubes.

  6. Why Lithium is Important?

  7. Neutral Pattering of Stem Cells

  8. A Boron Solution

  9. Plasmonic Gold Nanoparticles

  10. Building & Testing a Component of Synthetic Genetic Circuit in Mammalian Cells

  11. Optical Property of Single Wall Carbon Nanotube

  12. Why You Should Care About Crystals

  13. The Vital AMP

  14. The Importance of Fish Poop

  15. Terahertz Materials for 3D Printing

  16. Detecting Cancerous Pollutants

  17. Forever Chemical Gone Forever Using Nanotechnology by Converting PFAS Into Graphene Nanoparticles

  18. Designing a System that will prevent Membrane Fouling in the Event of a Power Outage

  19. Your Smart Brain

  20. BNNTs

  21. Mr. Waters Takes a Bath at the NEWT Water Treatment Facility

  22. Keep Our Dirty Clean

  23. Adaptations to Convection Cells

  24. Making a Self-Cleaning Anti-Scale Coating for Water Treatment Systems

  25. Nanocomposite Hydrogels

  26. Aggregation Effect of Near-Infrared Boron Difluoride Formazanate Dyes

 

Published Lesson Plans on TeachEngineering Site: 

  1. Bacteriophage Builder Challenge

  2. Biochar: Measuring and Improving Soil Function

  3. Bouncy Ball Factory

  4. Creative Engineering Design: Straw Bridges

  5. Crystal Creator: Testing the Resistance of Crystals

  6. Crystalline Cloth: Modeling Water Treatment Filters  

  7. Design Your Own Nano-Polymer Smartphone Case

  8. Designing Polymers to Clean Water  

  9. Engineering a Handcrafted Cement Shape

  10. Engineering a Photocatalytic Delivery System

  11. Engineering Self-Cleaning Hydrophobic Surfaces

  12. Engineering Silver Nanoparticles    

  13. Engineering the Perfect Gummy Candy

  14. Exploring Bioluminescence in Aquatic Animals

  15. Fabrication of a Resin Keychain or Keyring

  16. Having a Ball with Chemistry and Engineering

  17. Keep your Cool! - Design Your Own Cooler Challenge

  18. Lab Experiments in Rebuilding Soil with Biochar

  19. Light Up Your Machines with Biomimicry

  20. Magnetic Fields and Distance

  21. Making Dirty Water Drinkable

  22. Measurement Certainty: How Certain Are You?

  23. Mission Impossible: The Voltaic Protocol

  24. Much More than Pretty Colors

  25. Mystery of the Contaminated Water

  26. Nanotechnology Scavenger Hunt!

  27. Observing Cell Structures with Fluorescent Dyes

  28. Oil: Clean it Up! 

  29. Preventing the Zombie Apocalypse - Making Gene Therapy Safe!

  30. The Amazing Buckyball: How to Track Nanomaterials in the Human Body

  31. The Glow Show Slime Engineering Challenge

  32. The Search for Surfactants: What is the Best Soap?

  33. What Makes an Eruption Explosive?

  34. Biodegradable Husk Bags Design Challenge

  35. To Infinity and Beyond: The Amazing Hydrogels
